From the brige you got a nice view point on the canal. But the bridge by itself is not very beautiful. There is still some old arc but they've had some pitch on the ground...
A nice place to start your walk around the Old Town in Trondheim. Go early if you want to avoid crowds.
Very iconic bridge in the heart of Trondheim. Try to go there early to avoid huge crowds of selfie sticks users!

This is the oldest bridge in Trondheim and was a former drawbridge. It is a place to visit and take beautiful pictures of the Nidelva river and former warehouses in the embakment particularly when water is stagnant and mirror reflecting.
I would like to understand better what is the name of the river - got no time to look after everything myself - the Arch of Hope is spiritually harboured in Trondheim this night/
The Old Town Bridge is a Trondheim landmark that you can't help but find and visit as you walk around the city. From the bridge, the view of the old buildings along the waterfront is very scenic.
Nice brigde which has experienced lots of kisses and marriage proposals. I think it has elements of the chang lang in the Summer City in Bejing. Go there and give your girlfriend a kiss.
This bridge represents the town of Trondheim itself and lot of people is taking pictures walking on it. I liked very much, like all the rest of the town.
Looks really nice when it's sunny. Everyone who comes to Trodhaim should take a walk here. Nice bridge, nice houses, feeling like you're in Venice.
"Den Gamle Bybru" named: "Happiness Portal" is the name of the most photographed bridge in Trondheim. Very well preserved. Only for walking.
Very interesting old town bridge. Here you can take unique pictures and relax when looking at water and old houses. I recommend!

Lovely bridge, now restored. Pub at end of bridge which sells 100's of ales from around the world. Plenty of coffee shops with outdoor seating, all selling wonderful coffee/chocolate and cakes/sandwiches.
In the middle of the city, allows you to se the old merchant buildings from the river, and it's old. Not much more, but worth seeing while stuck in the city anyway

We walked through the old town towards the bridge before returning through the centre. Admittedly there were some good views, especially towards the Cathedral but little else.Walking down the riverside we stumbled on a Second hand warehouse which we found far more interesting.
Great views from the bridge and it takes you into a totally different place from bustling Trondheim.
Good view definetly a place to visit in Trondheim if you want to see the typical houses. The old bridge is really.
this is a must see place when visiting Trondheim. There is a bar in the corner also very good. And the small streets are very cute for a romantic walk

This is a starting point for a visit to many of the best spots in town. Photography view point from the bridge. The right spot for a Photo shoot. Overview of the sea houses along the river - on both sides. Access to the old town - pittoresque houses at Bakklandet. Up the hill
Buzzling with people sometimes, all alone at others. Great place for photo, and central for a lots to do.
This is a very beautiful place, just beside the river and sourrounded by coffee shops and restaurans. Is great just for walking o passing by while you're running aruound the city.

We had a day in Trondheim from cruise ship and had a walk around town centre after our tram ride,this sweet little bridge has good veiws of river and surrounding city,its a short walk from cathedral & its gardens and easy reach from St Olav's St,buses etc, Trondheim came across
Beautful, well dept bridge. A natural part of walking in the aera by Bakklandet and the Nidaros cathedral.
A little underwhelmed when we took a walk to the '2nd most interesting place' in Trondheim I'm afraid. A quick snap and was on our way!

I had no info on the history of this bridge when I visited, but it provides a nice view of the town along the water on both sides, so is worth visiting. If you're heading to the downtown area anyway, then definitely stop by. I believe this is only accessible via foot/bike, not

What a quaint location to visit. Just beautiful in winter with a nice fall of snow and at this time gives you a wonderful photo opportunity. Take the time to walk through this area and take in the atmosphere
An old bridge in a romantic environment. Offers a great view to old Trondheim. The bridge itself is an excellent example of good old building technology.
We walked across to get to Bakklandet. The view down river is fantastic. Lots of people here on sunny days taking photos. The padlocks are coming popular here too in case you are the marrying type.

The bridge is at the end of the town just below the cathedral. It is worth visiting at night when all lit-up and when the warehouses you view from the bridge are also illuminated. A fascinating part of old Trondheim.

Since the bridge is closed off to car traffic, it makes for an enjoyable place to check out the river near the city center. A rather simple bridge, but the surroundings make it a must see in Trondheim.

The bridge us not far from the centre of town and is attractive. It also leads to a rather charming old part of the town so good to include in a stroll around. Nice views of the river from the bridge. Snowing heavily today so it looked particularly picturesque.

Great old town area and street - walk along and grab a good Norwegian coffee and sweet bread and one of the small cafes. Take the time to enjoy the water views before you hit Sol Siden shopping and restaurants.

Just a bridge, but the design is pretty cool to me. Apart from that, the river looks nice that I took some photo on it. The building nearby is also full-of-Norwegian feel and makes Old Town Bridge a good place to take photo. PS: The bridge is not long, you can cross the the
A characteristic bridge in the city center. Closed for car traffic. Figures i several local songs as Lykkens Portal - Gate of Happiness.

Beautiful bridge of an old design. One one side of the bridge the beautiful cathedral stands tall, on the other the beautiful old town beckons with shops, cafes and restaurants. While on the river you have a great view of buildings lining the river, the university, the old town,
The oldest bridge to Trondheim down town is a good place to go and take pictures in different diractions. Also kinda romantic place to take your better half.
Just wander over it to the other side, it is a beautiful bridge, if you read on the history it makes it more special. Last time we were here it was in renovation.

The Bridge is very easy to find. Trondheim is quite a small town. Once on the bridge the view of all the coloured buildings on wooden stilts is really beautiful. Like picture postcard! With the right light the colours reflect on the water and makes a really lovely photograph.
This bridge needs to be crossed in order to reach the other,older side of town and it is very interesting.

We were in Trondheim just three hours between landing ship and plane to Oslo! But the time to see all the major Sightseeings this beautiful city! Thanks to this weather possessed! The architecture of the bridge is very interesting, and views of the city just lovely! Make a wish

Good postcard photo well lit and well traveled even in winter. clear river view. Get map from train station or hotel and read the sides of the buildings at intersections to figure out cross street names
Not exactly spectacular about the bridge. Can give it a miss unless you really have a lot of spare time.

This little bridge is great for taking photos as no cars go along it. It is lovely in the cold weather as it makes the bridge look beautiful. We followed one of th notes free tourist maps and it took us straight to this bridge. Easy to find, coffee shop over the other side.

A walking tour from the center of Trondheim pass Nidaros Cathedral over the Solsiden = The Sunny Side, make sure you cross the little river via this old bridge which also takes you through the older part of Trondheim. A beautiful walk full of history and charm
Perfect gateway between the two must see attractions in Trondheim. Visit at night to get pictures without a ton of people.
It was so nice to be able to walk across this old bridge and take pictures of the old houses along the river there. The bridge is on everyone's guide to the town.
Nice bridge, but not much to it... My girlfriend really liked it and made a lot of pictures of the river and the houses built on poles.

I guess this is the best place for photography in Trondheim. The iconic houses by the river, the river, the church, and the cozy Bakklandet could all be captured from this bridge. The bridge in itself is also nice.
This old bridge is well known in Trondheim as well in the rest of Norway. From the bridge you can make stunning pictures of Nidelva (the Nid river) and the old packhouses downstream.

Brilliant sunny morning, with I think the first frost of the year which made the surface very slippery, especially on the wooden parts. The water was calm so brilliant photo opportunity with reflections of the old warehouses in the water. Worth going to see as it is near the
I think it worth going to look this bridge. It offers a fantastic view of the university at Gløshaugen and a great view of the river and old boat houses.
This bridge is very beautiful but it is just a bridge but is a place that is worth seeing as there are some amazing views up and down the river.
..really not much more to say about it. Worth checking out if you're a tourist. Preferably on your way over to the old part of Trondheim.

I was surpriced on our city walk. Walked over the bridge and came to the old houses from old Trondheim , here is many nice little pubs and shops. Very nice walk and cosy atmosphere. I recomend a visit in this part of Trondheim.
This bridge is located in the most beautiful area of Trondheim. The bridge itself is nice, and the sorrounding area is good for a stroll.

Or so goes the song. Don't get me wrong, it is indeed a lovely old bridge, nicely located, and with nice views of the old town, the serene river and the rickety old pier warehouses that line both banks of the river (Nidelva). But, just being honest here, it is what it is.
Nice place to see the wharves. Good views and a peaceful walk. Take some good photos. Beautiful and nice.
There really only is the three portals to see, but then they are really nice. Also, it is only a few metres from the cathedral and well worth the minimal effort.
Wonderful and magical place! Great for photos and to look at how life goes on in Trondheim. A must go on spot very near cathedral of Nidaros.
The area is lovely...we walked the left and right sides of the canal...the lovely wooden buildings...stopped and had a picnic along the way...the bridge makes a nice photo opt.
It is a very nice part of the city, with a very active night life too. You can take beautiful pictures from here.

The old bridge takes you into Bakklandet, the old town, and the Fortress. Small wooden houses, some cafes and shops, and the bridge itself was a drawbridge whose workings are still there if you are curious about things mechanical.
Historically interesting. People from Trondheim go there to have their photo taken when tey get married. It is several hundred years old. Goog photo opportunity.

The bridge itself is nothing special, but the view down the river with the old warehouses lining the banks is definitely worth seeing, particularly in the evening light. Just across the bridge, you can have a laugh at the people trying to use the bicycle lift up the hill.
Yes it really is and old time bridge and some really great view as well. Plenty of restaurants nearby.

This little bridge is of a quite unusual style. It links the main centre of Tronheim to the Bakklandet district which leads up to the castle. There are pleasant views of the river and wharfs from it. You can get views of the bridge from a couple of places by the river where
One beautiful bridge with history. The view to the river is very beautiful you can see the old houses in the water and feel the fresh air from the sea.

Beautiful spot for. Keying various architecture in Trondheim. The bridge itself is interesting in how it is built and works, but the views in the vicinity of this bridge are spectacular in any direction. Enjoyed the time we spent in this area of town

Exceptional bridge with very nice view to typical colourful houses in Norway. I think, there is no normal bridge in the whole Norway, but 3 bridges in Trondheim are even above the average. A must in Trondheim, very beautiful place

It's a really nice bridge :) Not much to say about it, it's a bridge, there's a river.. But the view is nice, and if you're visiting Trondheim it's a nice walk from the town center ("Trondheim Torg" area), across the old town bridge and to Bakklandet.
Is a simple, charming bridge. But walk over it and enter an old, original part of the city. For us who has lived in Trondheim, yes, this is history and nostalgic.
Walking across the bridge provides the opportunity to see the old houses on both sides. Good place to take photographs.
Historical significance aside, standing on the bridge with the right lighting is a photographers dream
I just did not know a simple bridge (perhaps I call it simple because I do not know how important it should have been to people of a certain time) can be so fun to visit!

Trondheim is an attractive town, and from the bridge you can see the wooden warehouses reflected in the water. Along the canal there is some pleasant walking. You are there for the atmosphere and what you can see around you, rather than the bridge itself.
Beautiful old bridge that allowed nice pictures of the canal, surronding houses and The Backaland. Well maintaned aswell.
It is an attractive bridge but nothing special. It is great for crossing the river; which incidentally, is what it was built for.
Sure, it's a nice pedestrian bridge with some nice views, but it is a bridge. Look north and there is some great views of old houses and new boats, look south and there is a bend in the river!
The total district is great. The old city across the bridge is full of charming restaurants, boutiques, bars, and historical wooden houses. Nice view from the bridge.

I didn't find the bridge nothing of exeptional, but from this bridge you can have on one side a magnific view on the old typical houses on the canals of Trondheim. These houses are all in wood and with wood column basis as "palafitte". On the other side of the bridge you see
Trondheim is a beautiful city with lots to do and see. The bridge is beautiful and is an easy way to walk over to the older side of town and a lovely path along the river

The bridge is ok but not that interesting. However, the views of the coloured wooden buildings lining the waterfront are worth seeing from the bridge and a good spot for photos. Also wander around the back streets and down to the next bridge for interesting old architecture. I
This an opportunity for all travellers to discover a beautiful view from that bridge . You can see all old houses , the tower of castle and the river itself .
google: Historic red bridge. here you can admire the typical colorful houses of Trondheim
This bridge let me cross the river. Can definitely recommend to others that also want to cross the river. Works equally good from both sides too.
A beautiful bridge with beautiful flowers. It good for tourists and site seeing. A beautiful views in the heart of Trondheim city

text.wiki:
Nidaros Cathedral (Norwegian: Nidarosdomen / Nidaros Domkirke) is a cathedral of the Church of Norway located in the city of Trondheim in Trøndelag county. It is built over the burial site of King Olav II (c. 995–1030, reigned 1015–1028), who became the patron saint of the nation, and is the traditional location for the consecration of new kings of Norway. It was built over a 230 year period, from 1070 to 1300 when it was substantially completed. However additional work, additions and renovations have continued intermittently since then; the most recent changes were completed in 2001. Nidaros was designated as the cathedral for the Diocese of Nidaros in 1152. After experiencing the turmoil and controversies of the Protestant Reformation of the 16th century, it was taken from the Catholic Church by the newly established state Church of Norway in 1537, which adopted the teachings and reforms of Martin Luther, Phillip Melancthon and others, becoming an Evangelical Lutheran church. Nidaros is the northernmost medieval cathedral in the world.The cathedral is the main church for the Nidaros og Vår Frue parish, the seat of the Nidaros domprosti (arch-deanery), and the seat of the Bishop of the Diocese of Nidaros.  The Preses of the Church of Norway is also based at this cathedral. The large, stone church seats about 1,850 people and it was historically used as the site of coronation of the kings of Norway.


== History ==

Nidaros Cathedral was built beginning in 1070 to memorialize the burial place of Olav II of Norway, the king who was killed in 1030 in the Battle of Stiklestad. He was canonized as Saint Olav a year later by Grimketel, the Bishop of Nidaros (the canonization was later confirmed by the pope). It was designated the cathedral of the Catholic Archdiocese of Nidaros from its establishment in 1152 until its abolition in 1537 under the Reformation.Since the Reformation, it has served as the cathedral of the Lutheran bishops of Trondheim (or Nidaros) in the Diocese of Nidaros. The architectural style of the cathedral is Romanesque and Gothic. Historically it has been an important destination for pilgrims coming from all of Northern Europe.Along with Vår Frue Church, the cathedral is part of the Nidaros og Vår Frue parish in the Nidaros deanery in the Diocese of Nidaros.


== Building and restoration ==

Work on the cathedral as a memorial to St. Olav started in 1070. It was finished some time around 1300, nearly 150 years after being established as the cathedral of the diocese. The cathedral was badly damaged by fires in 1327 and again in 1531. The nave was destroyed and was not rebuilt until the restoration in early 1900s.
In 1708, the church burned down completely except for the stone walls. It was struck by lightning in 1719, and was again ravaged by fire. Major rebuilding and restoration of the cathedral started in 1869, initially led by architect Heinrich Ernst Schirmer, and nearly completed by Christian Christie. It was officially completed in 2001. Maintenance of the cathedral is an ongoing process.
The oldest parts of the cathedral consist of the octagon with its surrounding ambulatory. This was the site of the original high altar, with the reliquary casket of Saint Olav, and choir. Design of the octagon may have been inspired by the Corona of Canterbury Cathedral, although octagonal shrines have a long history in Christian architecture. Similarly, the choir shows English influence, and appears to have been modeled after the Angel Choir of Lincoln Cathedral.
It is joined to the octagon by a stone screen that fills the entire east side of the choir.  The principal arch of this screen is subdivided into three subsidiary arches: the central arch frames a statue of Christ the Teacher, standing on the top of a central arch of three subsidiary arches below him. The space above the principal arch, corresponding to the vault of the choir, contains a crucifix by the Norwegian sculptor Gustav Vigeland, placed between statues of the Virgin Mary and the Apostle John. Built into the south side of the ambulatory is a small well. A bucket could be lowered to draw up water drawn from the spring that originated from St. Olav's original burial place. (This was covered over by the construction of later cathedrals).
The present cathedral has two principal altars. At the east end of the chancel in the octagon is an altar at the site of the medieval high altar, behind which stood the silver reliquary casket containing the remains of St. Olav. This silver-gilt reliquary casket was melted down for coinage by Christian II and St. Olav's remains buried in an unknown location under the cathedral. The only relic known to have survived is a femur in a silver-gilt reliquary. Shaped as a forearm, it was given by Queen Josephine to St. Olav Catholic Cathedral in Oslo. The original reliquary casket was in the form of a church, with dragon heads on its gables. The dragons are similar to those carved on the gables of Norwegian stave churches. Surviving medieval reliquary caskets in Norway frequently also bear such dragon heads, for instance, that at Heddal Stave Church.  He was the church's and the kingdom's patron saint. The current altar was designed to recall in marble sculpture the essential form of this reliquary casket. It replaces the previous baroque altar, which was transferred to Vår Frue Church.
The second altar is in the crossing, where the transept intersects the nave and the chancel.  It bears a large modern silver crucifix. It was commissioned and paid for by Norwegian American emigrants in the early twentieth century, and the design was inspired by the memory of a similar silver crucifix in the medieval church. The medieval chapter house may also be used as a chapel for smaller groups of worshipers.
All the stained glass in the cathedral dates from its rebuilding in the 19th and 20th centuries.  The windows on the north side of the church depict scenes from the Old Testament against a blue background, while those on the south side of the church depict scenes from the New Testament against a red background.


== Organs ==

Two organs are installed in the Cathedral. The main organ was built by the Steinmeyer firm in 1930, and was erected in the north transept. It then had 125 stops. Installation of the Steinmeyer organ was commissioned in 1930 for the 900th anniversary of the Battle of Stiklestad. The organ was funded mostly by donations, particularly by Elias Anton Cappelen Smith. In 1962, the organ was heavily rebuilt and moved to the west nave. Many stops were removed; some of them were used to build a new choir organ. This organ was fully restored in 2014.The old Baroque organ built by noted German organ builder Johann Joachim Wagner (1690–1749) during the period 1738–40 was carefully restored by Jürgen Ahrend between 1993–94. It has 30 stops and is located at a gallery in the north transept.


== Tourist attraction ==
Today, the cathedral is a popular tourist attraction. Nidaros Cathedral is the site of the observation of Olav's Wake (Norwegian: Olavsvaka). This religious and cultural festival is centered upon the anniversary of the death of Saint Olav at the Battle of Stiklestad. Tourists often follow the historic Pilgrim's Route (Norwegian: Pilegrimsleden) to visit the cathedral for this and other events.


== Alleged bombing plot ==
The cathedral is also familiar to enthusiasts of Norwegian black metal, as it is featured on the cover artwork of De Mysteriis Dom Sathanas, the 1994 studio album by Mayhem. It was rumored that members of the band who had already been associated with the 
burnings of other Christian churches in Norway had planned to destroy the cathedral in relation to the release of the album. When police arrested former Mayhem bassist Varg Vikernes on 19 August 1993 they had found 150 kg of explosives in his home.

Ekroll, Øystein; Krokstad, Jill; Søreide, Tove, eds. (1995). Nidaros Cathedral: And the archbishop's palace. Nidaros Domkirkes Restaureringsarbeide. ISBN 978-8276930177.
Flekk, Torgeir (1983). Nidaros Cathedral: The Stained Glass. Nidaros Domkirkes Restaureringsarbeider. ISBN 9788290536003.
Hansen, Knut Ingar (1997). Pilegrimsgang til Nidaros (in Norwegian). Gyldendal Tide. ISBN 9788247800287.
Kollandsrud, Mari (1997). Pilgrimsleden til Nidaros (in Norwegian). Gyldendal. ISBN 9788205247864.
Luthen, Eivind (1992). I pilegrimenes fotspor til Nidaros (in Norwegian). Cappelen. ISBN 9788202132491.
Raju, Alison (2010). Pilgrim Road to Nidaros, The: St Olav's Way - Oslo to Trondheim. Cicerone Press Limited. ISBN 9781852843144.
Schirmer, Herman Major (2012). Kristkirken I Nidaros (in Norwegian). Nabu Press. ISBN 9781273581434.

text.quote: Soaring, gothic cathedral dating to 11th century, plus Bishop's palace with a crown jewels exhibit.
trip: When visiting Trondheim, a small visit to Nidarosdomen is more or less compulsory. The interior and exterior are beautiful. In other countries, like Italy, you will of course find hundreds of churches like Nidarosdomen, but not in Norway.

This lovely cathedral was sensitively lit to enhance the architecture of the building. Lovely rose stained glass window, intricate carvings including the striking font. The dedicated chapels were worth a visit, such as that for the fallen in WWII with its beautiful golden alter
We did a walking tour of the city and walked through the church gardens. Unable to go inside due to Covid but listened to the bells ring and enjoyed looking at the impressive gothic facade
Amazing Cathedral. Great history, also worth visiting the museums around it. Could easily spend a whole day here looking at all the details

Me and my friends were visiting Trondheim for a week and we of course had to see this magnificent church in the center of the city. The gardens around were nice and i found the cemetery beside quite beutiful really. We didn't get the chance to go inside, but i didnt found that
Great sight with a remarkable history. We had a fantastic guide who made the whole place and it’s history come alive.

The rose window is simply stunning - as is one side of the building that is breathtaking for its ornate stonework. You need an hour here to take photos. I arrived late evening at 630pm but was allowed to take a few photos. Came back next day and it’s stunningly beautiful. The
Very impressive and dominant piece of architecture in Trondheim. A must see when visiting the city. We were there a day the organ played.

We went to Nidarosdomen early in the morning and where the first people to visit that day. We decided to pay to go inside the church and the museum and we would recommend other people to do the same. The church was beautiful on the inside and the outside. It was cool to see the

We have toured the exterior and interior both over the years. Both experiences are exquisite. The cathedral is situated beautifully in Trondheim, and surrounded by an old cemetery with large trees. Nearby, the archbishop's home is also a beautiful structure full of history. The
The architecture of this cathedral is so intricate and unique. It's definitely the most beautiful cathedral I have seen so far. This must be one of Norway's treasure. Recommended.

My third visit to this cathedral. Please sign up for guided tours, then you get more of history. We got guiding to the cript and the general tour. Also take a stall to archbishop house just next to cathedral.

It costs around 12 euros for a ticket, which at first seems quite a large fee, until you realise they are using this money to restore the Cathedral. We visited in February during heavy snowfall. The outside was spectacularly imposing in these conditions. Inside is actually

Whilst the exterior of the cathedral is imposing, especially the west side, the interior is dark and lacks the colour of many European cathedrals eg Bayeux. The cost of entry is high (kr 120 £10)And there is very limited information in the church apart from electronic
Interesting cathedral, so much work and history. Beautiful setting in the snow. Gorgeous architecture. Trondheim is a wonderful place to visit all up. A must

You can only enter the cathedral if you pay an entrance fee - This didn’t feel very Christian. No access to the crypt or tower in the wintertime with no reduction in price and no photos or videos are allowed. That said, the cathedral was very impressive and the Crown Regalia
Just passed by, we didn't go inside but very beautiful outside. The grounds were very icy but got some lovely photos.

Travelling on a Hurtigruten 'Northern Lights Cruise' last October, we visited Trondheim. A guided tour of Nidaros Cathedral from the ship was bookable on board, but it was expensive, so we decided to do it ourselves. A town map of Trondheim was available on the ship, and it
Fantastic atmosphere inside and great Staff inside and in the visitors center. Great outside view. Impossible to get up in winter and during bad weather due to slippery ladder.

This was a lovely church to visit. Not only is it a wonderful living building that is steeped in history with crypts beneath, but it is also the final resting place of the Viking king Olav, who was the first to bring Christianity to Norway. This makes it a ‘must see’ for anyone

We spent in Norway 2 weeks. Idea was to visit all cities that used to be Norwegian capitals - Trondheim, Bergen and Oslo. The first official capital of Norway became the city of Trondheim. It occurred around 997. Trondheim became soon main religious center of Norway. Nidaros
Trondheim ‘s landmark . Definitely worth a visit . Tickets to see the interior are available at the next door museum .

Nice church. When we visited it, there was a special service of the Norwegian Airforce, with a big orchestra and choir. It certainly attributed to our visit. Also from the outside the church is very nice and impressive to see.
If you’re a history lover or just dance some Anglo Saxon style architecture, this is a must-go place. The details and ambience won’t let the visitors go uninspired.

I thoroughly enjoyed visiting the cathedral and looking around. I would love to have been able to take photos in the main area of the church. As well as the Cathedral, a visit to the museums next door are a must too. The key thing is to check opening hours as the museums and
This is a beautiful place to reflect and take in the amazing glasswork and history. The diorammas give you an excellent account of the history of the cathedral dating back to it's origin.
Picturesque cathedral close to Old Town. Beautiful grounds that are definitely worth a walk around. Close to Old Town Bridge.
Definitely can’t miss a visit to the Nidaros Cathedral when in Trondheim. Huge and amazing inside. Would’ve loved to take a tour. Great little cafe and gift shop next door.

Make sure to read up on the history of Trondheim, or get a guide, to truly enjoy this masterpiece. The graveyard has a lot of interesting people buried as well. The details are wonderful to explore. Also known from Mayhem’s De Mysteriis Dom Sathanas album.
The Nidaros Cathedral is an impressive building that has undergone extensive restoration. The facade is imposing and the statues fascinating. Tickets are obtained in the adjacent visitor’s centre.

In the past five years we have toured many churches and cathedrals in several European countries. The Nidaros Cathedral ranks as one of the top cathedrals to visit. Architecture is superb. The stained glass windows, in our opinion, surpass the rose window in the Cathédrale
Even though the ticket to visit the cathedral is quite expensive, the place is impressive and worth the ticket price.
A must see in Trondheim. This cathedral is magnificent and the architecture is amazing. We saw it with a guided tour and got a lot of background information on the cathedral and local history.

This cathedral is magnificent. We did not take the tour but, instead, walked through the building and felt the power of being in this amazing piece of history. The structure is beautiful as is the immense nature of various sections of the building. The organ pipes are massive.
Beautiful piece of Norwegian history and architecture Details are impressive. The massive construction can be seen from far in the city and is the central attraction of the old town
Good city bus tour and got to learn lots about the homes and the Norwegian way of life and history. The cathedral is huge and magnificent and a special guide takes you through the cathedral.
Very nice building and that is it. Nice, quick photo nothing else special around. True we did not get it, but it was still a nice place to visit.

We visited Nidaros Cathedral whilst in Trondheim on a Hurtigruten stopover. It’s about 30 minutes walk from the boat, but well worth it. We couldn’t go in as it was a Sunday & there was a service in process, however we stood in the porch area & listened for a few minutes to the

This is a beautiful cathedral both inside and out. You will need a ticket to get inside but it is well worth it. The one down side is that you are not allowed to take pictures inside. The outside architecture is pretty stunning and there are a number of vantage points from which
A beautiful Cathedralthat is worth paying a visit. Walk around it first, then get inside. It is a landmark building for sure.

This has to be on your list of things to see in Trondheim. This cathedral is beautiful and intricate and a must see for any visitor. I went early in the morning to get photos and it was so peaceful. Do it!
If you visit the town, this is a must, number one attaraction. Very impresive cathedral, and you see by the way was build how old it is. Nothing new inside. Pictures are forbiden.
Definitely a beautiful view. The attention to detail on the sculpting is amazing. It is definitely worth walking to if you are in the Trondheim area.

The locale is beautiful. Spend time walking around the Cathedral and the cemetery, before you go in to the building. The guided tour is a good idea, but rather infrequent. We bought the guide book for NOK 50, and it was useful. Do go down to the crypt - it is fascinating, the
Nice building with nice surroundings. it is worth strolling around. However a ticket is needed to enter
I have visited many churches in my life but this one is definitely number one in my list! It looks like a palace! something unique and worth seeing it!

Great cathedral but we could only visit it from the outside today which was a shame... but it a fantastic building and the sculpture outside are super interesting to see. Definitely a must if you are visiting Trondheim.

We were surprised to walk into the front courtyard and notice how much Nidaros resembles Notre Dame. Gothic architecture. Similar dual towers, very tall central spire, flying buttresses and of course the famous gargoyles. In fact Nidaros Cathedral is the world’s northernmost
Definitely worth a visit if you’re in Trondheim. There are poster outside which tells the story of the place. Also there’s a wee café right beside it.

If you are on a cruise that only gives you a couple of hours in port make the effort to walk here and you will also see the modern city centre on your way. The cathedral may come as a bit of a surprise as it might seem more like what you would expect in England or northern

An amazing cathedral in the centre of town. It is surprising it is still standing when you hear it was almost bombed. It does cost to enter and there are many places for some good photos. It also has a gif shop outside.

We were there on the first day of St. Olav's festival so the place was absolutely packed. It was also a Sunday so our tour of the cathedral was cut short. Nevertheless, we did get inside and got a lot of interesting info from the guide about the church and its place in Norwegian

If in Trondheim feel the urgent of a jump in the history visiting this amazing Gothic Dome. Don’t trust the negative reviews. Worth the 10 euro of the ticket (its embarrassing read people complaining about the ticket which allow to mantain such a Jewel in the perfect way.
A big and beautiful cathedral in the centre of Trondheim. Open for public, also guided tours inside and outside the cathedral :-)
Great venue, and remarkable church. They do charge an admission fee, but will not allow you to take pictures within the church. Still worth viewing it for your memories.
Probably the most magnificent cathedral of Norway. It’s possible to join tours that go up on the roof, you can enjoy beautiful sunset of the city from there. Suggested

Unexpected treasure, a Gothic cathedral (with a Nordic twist) this far north. Highlight of any visit to Trondheim. Lovely rose window mostly in red is beautiful. In the cathedral square is a gift shop/toilets (free) etc.

The Nidarosdomen is a dark but awesome building. It resembles mid European catholic cathedrals. Statues and gargoyles is part of the architecture. Colour full glass mosaic windows fulfills the impression of how a cathedral is supposed to look.

We bought a dual ticket for the cathedral and The Archbishop’s Palace as it was better value. Nidaros Cathedral is the world’s northernmost medieval cathedral and Norway’s national sanctuary. The cathedral is huge and very dark inside, beautiful stained glass windows and

We went to Nidaros Cathedral in the evening but it had closed down for the night. But this being the norternmost Cathedral in the world we went back in the morning. Could/should have stayed longer. It is nothing short of jaw dropping. I'm sure that others are much more so but I

The Nidaros Cathedral is also known as the Dark Cathedral, and this becomes evident once inside. The outside is very interesting, with many stories to tell in the stone carvings in the facade. The people of Trondheim have a good sense of humour with Bob Dylan’s face being used
Did the tours in English at both here and the archbishop's palace which were included in the ticket price and added interest. Would be handy to have a plan saying who the outside statues were.

Nidaros is well and truly set up as a tourist destination. You will need to go to a seperate building to buy your tickets. The building is at the back of the cathedral and there you will also find toilets and a shop. Tickets are 110 NKR. You are not allowed to take any photos or

A major stop on our Trondheim Tours tour and the church is an impressive site where we learnt the history of it, St. Olav and how still today Norwegians take a pilgrimage to the site. We then headed away from the site to turn the corner and see the amazing façade overlooking

The facade of this wonderful cathedral is incredible with hundreds of statues! The exterior is amazing with oodles of gargoyles and flying buttresses! The interior is beautiful! The only drawback is that they will not allow photography inside. The visitors center has a neat cafe
I didn’t visit the inside but from the outside it was spectacular. And until what I have seen now very uncommon to other churches in Norway but off course it’s a cathedral for that

We walked to the Nidaros Cathedral from the Hurdigruten Ferry Terminal while our Ferry was making an extend stop. The Cathedral is interesting, however they will not allow photographs to be taken inside, and the square in front is so small that even with a 28mm wide angle lens I

Built in 1070 over the tomb of St. Olav, Nidaros Cathedral is where royal coronations are held and is the northernmost medieval cathedral in Norway. One of the most stunning features is the Rose Window which depicts the Last Judgement. Originally of the Roman Catholic

Lot of things to see inside. 50 NOK for a gallery-trip is well spent money for a good view. But watch the narrow steps going up! Not for the claustrophobic’s ... Sit down a take a look around. Go down stairs.

Would absolutely recommend the guided tour around this historical cathedral. You get a lot of Nidarosdomens background history and the history of the area around with you. Very intresting. As for the cathedral it self it's a amazing building!

We often attend service in Episcopalian churches while we're traveling and our visit to the Nidaros Cathedral was no exception. The simplicity of this Cathedral was particularly impressive. Though Luthern, the high mass at 11:00 a.m. was very much like Episcopalian high mass.

This beautiful cathedral, now Lutheran, the farthest north gothic cathedral in the world, is a must see in Norway. The tour was informative and full of wry humor. The historic detail was was satisfyingly interesting. It was easy to spend several hours exploring.

Located in the center of the city, this striking cathedral has quite a history. Its original construction began in 1070 over the burial site of King Olav II. He died in 1030, was canonized as a saint, and became the Patron Saint of Trondenheim. The earlier church(es) were

A visit to Trondheim, Norway wouldn't be complete without a stop at the Nidaros Cathedral. If arriving by cruise ship, one can take a ship tour, or you can walk yourself from the cruise pier (about 1.5 mile thru the shopping zone) to the Cathedral. Upon approach you might feel

It has a medieval appearance but in fact you're looking at a brand new pseudo-gothic building. It lay in ruins for a few centuries and was restored only a hundred years ago. The history of its reconstruction is posted on the stands at the cathedral plaza. I spotted a few
The cathedral is amazing spectacular beautiful much to see and to take in . They have guides to explain all about the cathedral.

Trondheim is a beautiful city with a huge very photographic cathedral. The sun presented a problem for taking pictures of the side so if this interests you you might want to research when the light will be best for the type of images you want.

This is only an impression from the outside, since we didn’t get a chance to visit the interior of the cathedral. The grey color creates a somber look, and the architecture is not as impressive as cathedrals from the same era in France, for example. Maybe more interesting

An amazing, if overly crowded place. It's a bit of a walk from the cruise ship docks (actually only maybe a mile at most), but you'll get to see the center of town and get some exercise on the way. The Cathedral is stunning, a true work of art and must-see attraction.

After all the churches and cathedrals that you visit across Europe, this is a grand example of something different. A mix of styles, but still gives that dark and ancient feel of something built to be a presence in a place. Stained glass window at the west is 'rose' like and

The outside is beautiful but we didn’t feel like paying to go inside (we thought it was quite expensive). Instead we walked around the cathedral and sat in the shade admiring the building. If you’re on a budget it’s worth knowing the war/arms museum nearby is free.

We walked around the Cathedral and it was amazing in and of itself, so we bought tickets for a guided tour of the inside of the Cathedral and the ticket we bought also included the adjacent museums with the Crown Jewels of the Norwegian royals and other history. The Cathedral

Visiting Trondheim equals a visit to the church Nidaros. It took 150 years to renovate. The towers on the west facade weren't there originally, and were built in the 1950's. Take five minuts in front of the church, just to look at it and admire the stone construction in a

The Nidaros cathedral is a fantastic church, built in both romanic and gothic style. You can take part on guided tours in norwegian, english, french or german language. If you have no klaustrophobia, you can climb up to the tower and have a wonderful look over the city of
The mostly restored cathedral in Trondheim with many tour groups allowed inside at once. This makes the place feel packed and loud at times. Go down into the basement to visit the crypt

Built purportedly over the reburial site of Saint Olaf, the cathedral is striking, all the more so when you realize its size for what was then a very small town in northern Norway. You need a ticket to enter [mine, combined with the Archbishop's Palace, was 200 krones]. The
Nidaros Cathedral is a must to see when visiting Trondheim. We highly recommend to take guided tour. With our guide Emil we have learnt quiet much new in easy and entertaining way. Thank you, Emil.

This cathedral, the northernmost Gothic cathedral in Europe, is a beautiful building from both the outside and the inside. The outside is decorated with many statues imbedded in the building, while the inside has beautiful stained glass windows. The cathedral itself has a long

We were at the cathedral as part of a special event sponsored by our cruise ship. Apparently the first time that’s happened! I understand they do have various concerts throughout the summer months. Cathedral is beautiful inside and out with fine stained glass windows. Am

Our group chose to take a private tour of the Cathedral including Chapels & Crypts together with the Archbishop's Palace & Crown Regalia. I booked online prior to arriving in Norway. The booking process was very easy although communication between the booking department & me

We have visited a number of Cathedrals over the years and this is one of the largest. The stained glass windows are outstanding. There are over 9,000 pipes for the organ. We were lucky to arrive just at 10:00 a.m. for a 30 minute information session on the origins of the
Very interesting to visit this old and majestic church full of 1000 years of history from the viking Kings and christening of Norway placed in beautiful Trondheim
Went there on a cruise and the transfer stopped here. We had a tranquile walking around the impressiv Cathedral. Would go there again.

I was in Europe on business and decided to spend my free weekend in Trondheim ahead of meetings Monday and Tuesday. The Cathedral was my first stop on Saturday (after the Festningsparken Parkrun). It was a beautiful cathedral that inspired awe at the work required to build the
We had an amazing private tour of Nidaros Cathedral. I would recommend that everyone do a private tour. We were able to see hidden chapels and learn of the history of the Cathedral.

We visited in January when there was abundant snow to beautify the spacious grounds. The near twilight of the short winter day provided golden light for exterior photographs. Unfortunately, despite charging for admission, interior photos are not permitted. It said to be built

This cathedral goes back to 1070s when the Vikings were around and Trondheim was the capital of Norway. It is a bit in your face with the church making so much money in the tourist trade with very high fees to see the church and so much stuff for sale.

The cathedral is wonderful! stone exterior that is still being restored for the last 140 years. Bring your binoculars to look at the gargoyles and other carvings that seem to be at every possible location. Did not take the tower tour but that could not possibly have made the
It's a beautifully made churche( cathedral) You must go inside to see the development of this beautiful masterpiece ❤️❤️❤️ And the outside, breathtaking 😍😍 Enjoy this to winter pictures ❤️
Nidarosdomen is really the most beautiful catedral in northern Europe. The arcitekture of the kathedral is wonderful. IT is an amazing building with an impressive arcitecture.
A walk from our cruise ship to the Cathedral. We enjoyed the exterior information panels and the great cathedral exterior. Chose not to do the interior tour (at a cost). Great stonework.

This is a destination for individuals, couples, families, and groups. We embarked from our Hurtigruten coastal cruise ship from the pier in Trondheim. It is about a 20 to 30 minute walk, depending on your distractions from glimpses of old Trondheim on the waterfront with its

It worth visiting the cathedral and museum that tells a very long story of the cathedral building and renovation, with big photos of major sculptors worked on it. Organ concert is not a classic concert, but rather a wordless pray, when organ sounds from all sides of the

The cathedral is a beautifully ornately carved structure. The grounds were lovely to walk. There are large posters explaining the history and work being done on the church. There is a large gift shop, cafe and rest rooms in the building next to the Cathedral.
We went to Sunday mass and our familiarity with the service meant language was not a barrier. The singing was sublime.
Big rip off. Bought a combination ticket for cathedral and bishops palace but the palace was just one room with the royal regalia not a tour of the palace. Far too expensive.
Unique and special facility. The northside has several rows of statues of more than 60 religious persons. This should not be missed! And, an excellent gift shop.

The building is impressive and the façade has a remarkable number of statues that left us wondering who everyone was (especially the fellow with 3 heads at his feed). However, once inside, there was a group setting up for a concert later that day and there was no place to find

We were told that there are 172 steps and that it will be narrow, in case we are afraid of narrow spaces. We totally thought that this amount of steps is manageable and we know that we won‘t panic, so we decided to do the tour. The tour guide walked in the front, unaware of what
Amazing place to visit. Alot of space around to just sit and look at the cathedral. It is also amazing to go inside.
Great place to visit for a few hours. Beautiful cathedral. Not sure the combined ticked with the ?museum and crown jewels is worth it. Not much to see there bit the cathedral is stunning
this is the home of my great grandfather so we loved Trondheim. the cathedral was breathtaking inside and out

Outside it is an architectural masterpiece surrounded by some gardens, and nearby an excellent visitors centre and cafe. Inside it is dark, and photography is not allowed, but many people were taking photos. We had a guided tour about 30 minutes, some of interior is really old,
This cathedral is beautiful to look at with stunning architecture but the inside was a little disappointing.There was very little on the inside to inspire.

My wife and I visited the Cathedral one afternoon recently around 1500 hours and found it not too busy at all. We had visited the outside of the building several hours earlier in the morning and the whole courtyard area was absolutely mobbed with tour groups. This was not the

Bad news: it was a public holiday so there were no guided tours in the morning. Good news: we got to sneak inside when the choir was singing, and we had a look around. In the Archbishop's Palace next door there is a lot of information about the history of the cathedral.

Yes, this is the northern most gothic cathedral in Europe. Yes, this is the largest cathedral in Scandinavia. Yes, this is where the Norwegian royalty is blessed and is the pride of the country. But the Nidaros Cathedral has a very interesting history. Started in the 1100's, it
But you need to read about it ahead of time or have an excellent guide. There are many hidden gems - which saint on the exterior has Bob Dylan’s face?

Very plain inside but very beautiful in its starkness. Excellent Cathedral guide but because I was on a bus tour, couldn't look around enough. Disappointing that one is not allowed to take photos, although I managed a couple of sneaky ones!

Nidarosdomen are a beautiful cathedral for sure, but the best thing about it is its location, much unlike many of Europes cathedral this one have enough space to really shine in its full glory. The gift store is outside, so you can enter the cathedral and truely enjoy the
There are tours in different languages here. The setting is very peaceful and the have music performances with a Bach organ.

This is the Cathedral that is said to house St. Olav. There is much history here and the building is truly incredible. You can also go down to the “crypt” and up into the towers, which is very cool. The entrance fee is not much, and it is well worth it. If you don’t won’t to

A magnificent building: certainly not something you would expect to see so far north. Words can't describe the structure, but it is a must see when you're visiting Trondheim. Allow two hours to visit the tower as well.

The history of the Cathedral is very interesting, the building is impressive, but without explanation many things will go unnoticed. Also is really nice if you get the chance to hear the wonderful organ they have!

This cathedral is truly worth a visit It equals Notre Dame maybe even surpasses it Sadly you can’t take photos of the interior however sometimes it’s best just to really look at all the artwork and detail and be inspired by the artisans who have created this place over the

I think this cathedral is worth visiting, even if you are not particularly religious. It is in excellent condition (no scaffolding!) and just gorgeous inside. I was surpised to see this large a (mostly) Gothic cathedral so far north, with all the wooden buildings everywhere else

Rather big cathedral, located quite centranly, has nice garden outside with lots trees and flowers as well as some monuments to the fallen in the wars. Did not have a lot of time but enjoyed it just walking around
I walked here from the cruise ship port. I'm not religious so had no interest in going into the Cathedral but took a photo and checked out the gift shop. Everyone said that it was lovely inside.

This is a very beautiful 948- year-old cathedral. Architectural style is Romanesque and Gothic. So much history and beauty. This is a cathedral but even not-so-religious people will be able to appreciate this architectural and spiritual treasure. The rose window is best viewed

It is something amazing. If you ever visit Trondheim, this place is a must visit. Simply Beautiful ! The biggest one in Norway. Incredible views outside and fantastic interiors inside. Amazing art work - just magical. Worth to seeing! Huge, magnificent, absolutely unreal

Cathedral is beautiful. Upon entering, the docent at the desk greets you. The day we were there, a very knowledgeable teacher in training spoke to us for a long time about the history of Norway, especially during WW II. He was extremely interesting and friendly, very patient
The Cathedral really deserves a visit! It is beautiful. The visit is quite expensive (~20€) but if you enter during the services it is free of charge. The organ service is excellent!

Built over the tomb of St Olav the Viking who brought Christianity to Norway. Fine building with many , many, statues to ponder over. There is a visitor centre , shop and toilets near the main entrance. Well worth the effort , even through the snow.
Beutifull place. One of the must see places in Trondheim. Also recomend thr archbishops palace that is wall to wall.
I wasn’t able to go inside however the Cathedral is still worth visiting to see the incredible entrance and outside detailing.

This was a visit from the Hurtigrute cruise ship. Many people took a taxi, but we walked there, only about 20 minutes despite the snow on the ground. It's a beautiful building inside and out. We had a very good guide, and learned a lot about the cathedral, the city and the
This was a beautiful cathedral well worth a visit. Paid 110 Nok for guided tour but no photographing was allowed inside.

An absolutely breathtaking cathedral. I visited it on a rainy day but I fee like sun would bring it to full life. It has info points to tell the history of this mixed style cathedral. The only con is that you're not allowed to take photos inside, which is a shame, because it's
Such amazing place! The ticket is 110 nok including guided tour. Photographing inside is not allowed.
Not much I can say but this was a beautiful Cathedral well worth the time to visit and to see. I only wish was I got to hear 1000 pipe organ.

Nidarosdomen was beautiful to see, the detail was amazing inside and outside. In order to enter the church you first must visit the gift shop which is adjacent to the church and purchase a ticket. While in the church there was a man playing the organ. The song choice was
This cathedral is a must for visitors to Trondheim. It’s beautiful and with the snow it was very special.

This is definitely worth a visit. We were lucky to see it on a beautiful blue skied, snowy day and it looked stunning. We got some amazing photos in the cemetery with lovely long shadows. The architecture is quite stunning both inside and out, it was a shame not to be able to

It is a grand majestic structure next to Nidelva which was witness to several major historical events in Norway. It was where coronation ceremony was performed until it was abolished. It is a must visit in Trondheim, be it both summer or winter
This is a beautiful cathedral with great history. The architecture and history is interesting and you will need the English speaking tour to get the details if you don’t speak Norwegian.

Nice church - from the outside. St. Peter in Rome, the High Dome in Cologne, Notre Dame in Paris - you can enter there for free all the day and visit or pray. I WILL NEVER EVER PAY 110NOK TO ENTER A CHURCH Instead we have visited the local church for homeless people and made a

Visited as part of a city tour of Trondheim, from a Hurtigruten Cruise. Extremely good guide in the cathedral, called Emile. Gave us an excellent, potted history of the building and of St Olav. Lovely building and would have liked more time to look round. Drawback was not being

I live in Trondheim, and I still am amazed by the amount of details there is on this building. Go inside and take a look or take a tour to get some more history. Don`t forget to take a stroll "behind" the church next to the river. Nice part of Trondheim

We had arrived on the Hertigruten ferry and decided to walk to the cathedral which opened at 9am. We bought our tickets in the shop/cafe which wasn’t cheap at around £24 for the two of us. We somehow ended up with a tour group and had a wonderful guide who was a french/Norwegian

Lovely church which has been extensively but sympathetically restored. Not a huge amount to see but the interior is so beautiful just take a while to sit and soak in the peaceful surroundings. No photos or video allowed.

The cathedral grounds cover a large area and include the Archbishops Palace and The Church of our Lady. There are also large park-like grounds around the cathedral and historic graveyard. We were there in late July during the St Olaf Festival, which relates to the supposed
This 1000 year old church is an important part of the christian history. You can walk around and enjoy the architecture and scultures from th eoutside or join a guided tour inside
I was too early to see inside the church, but the imposing cathedral ... one of the city's major landmarks ... looked magnificent in the early morning light.
The ground was covered with snow, so it looked pristine and pretty, the church was pretty to the eyes.

Truly a marvelous Cathedral . Trondheim’s main landmark. Imposing both from the front and the back and reminds me of the Cathedral of Norte Dame. High vaulted ceilings with Rose windows . There were 2 steel pipe organs, one of which was enormous . Gorgeous Interiors , sadly no
Took a lot of photos of the outside.... Gargoyles and figures. Inside was closed when we visited as was the gift shop.

Stunning architecture and ornate carving, especially over the front entrance. Equally beautiful inside, though there is a charge for entry, and no photos allowed inside. The organ meditation was also enjoyable, though be aware that you are requested to stay seated throughout:

Very impressive cathedral. A little bit dark inside, which tends to hide some of the amazing features to some degree. The cathedral is many hundreds of years old. The soaring ceilings and intricate stone work are quite breathtaking. The grounds are very well maintained and

If you ever go to the city of Trondheim this is the place you must visit. Fantastic cathedral with amazing sculptures and architecture. Worth a visit both in daylight as well in the night. Historically one of the most important symbols in Norway.

This cathedral just had me sitting on a park bench looking up in silent awe. I came somewhat reluctantly (how many cathedrals can one girl see in a life time) but was glad I came. The carving is so intricate, so varied that each corner deserves attention. The gargoyles are

Thoroughly impressive cathedral (didn’t go inside) from all sides, and beautiful cemetery and grounds. Importantly, the cafe does good coffee and is a nice place to view the front of the cathedral on cold days!

This ancient cathedral almost takes your breath away. Nidarosdomen was listed at the place where Olav the saint's body was dug down after the battle at Stiklestad. The cathedral was started already in the eleventh century, and was probably almost finished around 1300. The
This is definitely worth a visit. The exterior is more impressive than inside which costs £10 to enter .No photographs are allowed and men must remove headgear

We were on a Hurtigruten cruise and based on the excellent TripAdvisor reviews we decided to walk to the beautiful church. Please note to turn to the right after the 2 traffic circles when walking from the pier! You will see the spire of the church. We got lost and had to

My husband reckons this cathedral beats anything he saw in Italy....you’d have to say that’s saying something. The outside is amazing the 50 or so stoned carved statues a couple of the statues are of Bishop Sigurd holding the heads of his three nephews in a bowl, kings etc it’s

Although heavily restored over many years starting from the 19th century this is an impressive building reminiscent of English cathedrals such as Lincoln. A tribute to the skills of medieval builders and craftsmen (some of whom came from England), a visit to this building that
Must visit while in Trondheim. Very interesting site with 2 museums plus the Church. Get the combination ticket and visit all three.

A little on the expensive side at 100NOK entry, still what can you do? Very nice and interesting church with lots of history, there is an information station in the church which explains most aspects.
This is a must when in Trondheim, make sure you buy the ticket that takes you to the dome or else, go to a concert inside it
A beautiful cathedral, medival and humble. So unlikly so far north. The goal of the pilgrims,on their sanctuary north. Olav the holy king of Norway.
This building is visible almost from each spot on the city center. To get inside you need to buy a ticket. Beautiful exterior especially at the entrance.

Was going to do an interior visit but the cost put us off. Instead we just had a walk around the exterior. Very impressive with lots to see in the grounds. Would have definitely gone inside if it was more reasonably priced.

A magnificent cathedral surrounded by a graveyard that was lovely to walk around. Unlike many cathedrals such as Notre Dame, it is light and airy inside. The many chapels and altars are all part of it being the burial site of St Olav. One altar in particular is worth taking a
Had a few hours to spend in Trondheim on a businesstrip, and chose to see Nidarosdomen. It was a rainy day, and the cathedral was closed, so we just got to see the exteriour.

This beautiful Cathedral is fascinating, but there are blocked areas you must walk around, and you cannot take photos. It is the destination for pilgrims from all over Norway. You will enjoy the English tour. We didn't have enough time inside nor around the beautiful grounds.

On a wet and windy Sunday, we visited this wonderful cathedral when our Hurtigruten ship docked for a few hours. It's about a 15 minute's walk from the dock, and well worth seeing - not a lot else to do as the town was really quiet! We were in awe of the interior of the

Even if you're not a church/cathedral tour person, this is an impressive place to see. Centuries to build, the story of Nidaros is very interesting - not only from a historic point of view, but how its a pilgrimage site. I highly recommend the English tour - a nice way not only

This medeival cathedral, the most northern in the world. This was the most beautiful cathedral I have seen in Norway. So majestic and filled with about 1000 years of history. A moment I will treasure forever :)
An amazing building from the outside, but it has very restricted opening times, so I never got in! Plan ahead! It does have an associated visitor centre and shop - but also closed by 3pm.
If you are going to Trondheim, this is one of those "must see" places. Beautiful cathedral, and surounding area.

Be sure and give yourself enough time to take in all the aspects of this spectacular building. The pipe organ is absolutely remarkable. We were fortunate to hear it being played and to have a tour in English. By also visiting the Archbishops museum you get a more complete

Nidaros Cathedral is a unique cathedral, with Gothic style & Roman architecture. First place where I saw family graves - looks like unique characteristic of this place. Also - only noticeable architecture in Trondheim.
It looks like Notre Dame and is almost as grand (you need Paris for that). Definitely a major attraction in Trondheim and very beautiful.

The Cathedral in impressive both on the inside and outside. The stonework is amazing and when you stand inside you just feel so small as you have the inside stone walls rise to the vaulted ceiling. If visiting Trondheim you simple have to visit the Cathedral.

Beautiful gothic/medieval church. I was lucky enough to hear the organ being played whilst inside and the acoustics are incredible! Lots to look at inside and plenty of space to wander around. Unfortunately you are not able to take photographs which is a shame. When I went

Norway's national shrine and Royal Benediction Church- some of the most amazing stained glass I have ever seen. It was built over several centuries between 1070 and 1300 so there is this sense of awe . The gargoyles outside are stunning in detail.

An impressive building with some interesting features inside: the gigantic rose window and stained glass saints at the west end of the nave, the alter in the east and the Sami sculpture in the south transept. Outside the west front is powerful and the green spire stands out
Unfortunately it was closed when we arrived but it's worth going there even just to see the outside, a fantastic building!

This cathedral is more than amazing than I expected, we were simply wowed by the sophisticated architecture itself. The medieval history of the cathedral is one of the most beautiful we have ever seen. Although we did not manage to do an inside tour, a round at the outside of
This thousand year old cathedral has been burned down several times and reconstructed in the 19th century. It has an impressive organ which were able to hear. It is impressive inside and out.

The front of this cathedral from the outside is jaw dropping. One of the most spectacular architectural sights I have ever seen. If going inside, buy the combined ticket for the crown jewels and the palace as well. It is 180kr, otherwise they are 100kr each. I would also

We had been before but on this morning we were all invited in to hear the Organ played as a concert. Nidarosdomen is the largest construction in Norway from the Middle Ages. Don't miss the crown jewels or the burial tombs below.

The Cathedral and the grounds are both beautiful. There is a charge to enter the Cathedral but the grounds are available without cost. A Tour Guide will take you through the entire Cathedral and explain the history dating from the 13th Century. St Olaf was buried here. NO
Awesome history & architecture. Great value with the crown regalia. The guided tour is worth the time. Available in multiple languages.

My guide book states that it is only 1/2 mile from the Market Square. Having said that it must be another 1/2 mile to walk round it. The Original Church was erected around 1075. The oldest parts are late Norman & Gothic. Of particular note are the modern stained glass windows,

Yesterday (Sunday) I was lucky enough to attend church service at Nidarosdomen, a gothic cathedral with a breathtaking interior. Highly recommended to anyone who is not afraid of Norwegian sermons and songs!

Beautiful cathedral that seems a bit out of place. It's a very large, gothic cathedral, at the edge of town, with an amazing façade and stained glass windows. It's an easy walk from the port, but will take 20-40 minutes depending on your pace. Admission to see inside the

We planned our day in Trondheim around visiting the cathedral on English speaking tour. There were many tours at the same time, in different languages with independents sprinkled in. Very chaotic, although July was probably the busiest time. Some tours may have been private

This is the best reason to visit Trondheim. The cathedral is absolutely amazing. There are events going on throughout the day, so go in the morning to plan your time there and in the other nearby museums. Your tickets are only good for one day.

This was our second time visiting the cathedral, and this time we spent more time in the church to see all the sights. I'd strongly recommend the combination ticket, for the cathedral, museum, and crown jewels, although if you're really rushed for time, the cathedral is clearly
Although similar to other gothic churches it is impressive and interesting. The guides are good at conveying the story of this place.

If you are interested in history or medieval architecture this is a treat. The front of the building is staggeringly intricate with many saints statues. There are no pictures allowed inside at all. But the tour I took included a booklet with photos of the inside so no
Very good guided tours with competent guides that tell a lot of interesting facts in a easy to understand way.

If you are at all interested in Norway, it’s history and it’s people buy a combined ticket (NOK180 US$22.00) for entry to the Archbishop’s Palace Museum, the Armoury and Resistance Museum, the Crown Regalia and the Nidaros Cathedral. Leave the cathedral to last. While the

The building is amazing to see when visiting Trondheim. A friend who is local advised me to behold its facade and save money on entrance since, as most gothic cathedrals, the best part to see is the facade. Still really beautiful :-)

We visited this place while on a cruise. We knew that this was not a free attraction as is the case with many churches around the world. Finding out the very high cost of the ticket to visit this attraction convinced us it was not really worth it for us. We walked around the
Such a beautiful place. The church is unforgettable. Lots to do here and very family friendly! Be sure to buy the full ticket. You will save lots of money

Entrance fee includes Crown Jewels and museum. Cathedral was restored to gothic plan from 1869-2001 so the effect is harmonious. History display in transept is good: pillars with touch screen in multiple languages. St Olav shrine is a pilgrimage focus. No photography allowed in
A very beautiful cathedral. It’s worth to buy a ticket for all 3 museums/exhibitions. The palace is also very nice as are the crow jewels. All very beautifully displayed.

We decided to take the guided tour of this magnificent Cathedral, which we highly recommend. The personal touch of the tour guide ensure you get above and beyond in the historical information surrounding this beautiful place. The 4 hours we were there really only scratched the

bought the combo ticket with entrance to crown regalia. There was a guided English tour, which was informative. There are also info panels where you can learn more about the history, architecture and features of the Cathedral. Price is a bit steep, but the Cathedral is

Visited here on a combination ticket for the crown jewels and other museum. Wonderful old building and well worth a visit. Very informative tour in English explaining everything of significance about the cathedral and was able to answer my question as to why the Royal Navy
Beautiful architecture and surrounding cemetery / grounds. Note that the cathedral opens at 9.00am for visitors, so don't go too - early as we did!
We came several times in this church. The first time was at the Pilegrimsservice. We came 10 minutes before in the Kapittelhus. That was an excellent end of our Pilgrimage to Trondheim.

We did not expect such a large and impressive cathedral here. It cost about $25 for two of us just for the basic visit. But it came with a 30 minute guided tour in English, and was well worth it. Gorgeous organs and stain glass windows, but the altar and side chapels are less
We were here for orgel concert and it was an amasing experience with the renovated Steinmeyer orgel in best form.

The size of this Catherdral is very impressive among the other structures in Trondheim. We especially enjoyed looking at the intricate fascade. We just missed the English tour so had to read from the kiosks inside and maybe we did not get the full impression because of this but

In addition to touring the outside we also went inside but being pressed for time didn’t take the walking tour. Very expensive for a short visit but it does help pay for the upkeep. The grounds are beautiful with plots of shady trees among the old headstones.
Absolutely stunning Cathedral with charming local University students to guide,serve refreshments in the spacious cafe area. Unmissable experience.
Worth a visit. Big, but among the smalles cathedrals in Europe. We heard a beatiful organ concert while in the church.

There are rich details both outside and inside the cathedral, which you can spend hours studying. Unfortunately photos are not allowed inside, which limits the possibility to take home some of the personal memories. Coming back as a tourist 47 years after we got married in this

With a wonderful view over Trondheim or Nidaros as it was called way back. You can't feel but humble to see how wonderful the construction of the cathedral is. The craftmanship is outstanding. If in Norway you can't miss it.

The Nidarosdomen is Norways contribution to big old gothic architecture. There is not that much unique about this church, it is huge and has very elaborate stained glass. We went on a Saturday and enjoyed the free organ concert and a brief prayer service. This was formerly a

We were on a guided tour in this imposing cathedral. Well worth visiting. I have been here for 50 years ago and the cathedral is still very impressive. Only one thing bothered me. Very near the cathedral they have built a huge visitor’s center with ticket office and gift shop.

The cathedral has undergone phenomenal renovations. To appreciate the renovations, you should also head over to the archbishops palace museum. You can purchase a ticket for the cathedral and two museums at a significant savings. Take your time exploring the cathedral. Don't

It would be a shame to visit Trondheim without going here. Get the full option ticket and check out all the museums; also pay another 50 kronor to climb the 172 stairs that give you a view from the cathedral. And while at the archdiocese museums, be sure to peel off to see the

Lucky enough to attend a warm, fascinating organ concert at this beautiful cathedral. The rector of the cathedral was a very welcoming man, and the organ master incredible at his art (with an organ with 10,000 pipes that plays from 4 or 5 places in the cathedral, it truly is

Well worth 180 kroners for the three. Just a wonderful cathedral.. believe it or not it was only complete this decade.. but the timeline is amazing. Had a wonderful english tour guide...she had excellent english and was humourous with the information. If you are a fan of

We were so lucky to have an organ recital, mixed with some background history, arranged for us on our trip to Trondheim. The organ master played some wonderful music that showed off this remarkable organ/s. Such a privilege to listen in such a remarkable space - really grateful
Unfortunately we haven't made it to the inside but even from outside it is a very impressive Building with lots of small details to discover.

Well worth the fee to have a good look around, you can have a group tour but we went around by ourselves. very interesting including the crypt. Organ was being played just wished we had more time to listen to it. Wonderful suroundings. note. It would be a good idea to have a

This is one of Northern Europe’s oldest and largest cathedrals and is well worth visiting. There are English tours on the hour and taking one will greatly enhance your visit. They are still working on the cathedral a thousand years after commencing it - for proof of this you can
When ever I am in Trondheim, I love to visit that place. It is so fascinating. very close to city center and easy access. Nice food is also there, small suveniour shopping can also be done.

The destination for the Pilgrims of Norway. There are tours of the church offered as part of the price of admission and they are reasonably well presented. Our guide clearly had much more information and knowledge of the church and the society than he could compress into 20

We visted twice, once on a short visit from the Hurtigruten ship and then again on our return during a 2 day stopover. You need at least 90 minutes to cover everything. If you are not on a prearranged tour and have the time to spare (about 5 hours) then get a combination ticket

This is a phenomenal cathedral!! This must have dominated the whole area when it was built - a demonstration of power! A ship from outer space 😀 The location down to the river is nice. I am glad I had the opportunity to see this.
The churches and cathedrals from some time doesn't impress, me, but this time was different. Nidrsdome is awesome building, with very impressive space inside, and beautiful stained glasses.

We were on a pre-arranged tour with an English-speaking docent who was very knowledgeable. Large structure, hard to take it all in on a short tour. The history and architecture are fascinating, but no pictures (even without flash) are allowed inside.

We got there in the late afternoon and were very impressed with the cathedral, grounds, and gift shop. Took a tour of the cathedral and were able to find out about the history of the structure by the interactive digital info center. The gift shop had a lot of great gift items.

The tour was informative but not entirely necessary. There were no hidden panels nor facts that couldn’t be gleaned elsewhere. Didn’t go up and didn’t go down. If you enter during a service you don’t need to pay. It is quit spectacular in its own right.
Definite top 10 things to see in Trondheim. Beautiful inside and out, wonderful gift shop, coffee shop and museums have first class displays. Worth spending some time here.
This is the most beautiful cathedral, both in scale and skill. The architectural features are beautiful and the location offers a calm haven.

The cathedral is so very impressive from the outside and the inside doesn’t disappoint either. Just amazing. It was very wet and snowing when we visited and the grounds and graveyard were waterlogged so we couldn’t look around outside much but, what we did see looked like it
